node.title: ‘There’s a dignity in being taken seriously’: First Nations books find home in innovative program
node.alt: An Aboriginal woman standing in front of a corrugate iron background
node.description: In the decade since black&write! began, it has shepherded acclaimed works by First Nations writers including Nardi Simpson, Ali Cobby Eckermann and Claire G. Coleman.
node.content:
["Nardi Simpson has always been a storyteller, and for the last 20 years the Yuwaalaraay woman has channelled that skill into her work as a founding member of Indigenous folk duo Stiff Gins.", "But when she noticed her songs were starting to get long, she decided to try her hand at writing a novel instead.", "\"I did a course at Writing New South Wales called 'Year of the Novel' because I thought I'm gonna have to learn how to do some of this,\" she says.", "When the course finished, Simpson's tutor encouraged her to enter her manuscript Song of the Crocodile into the 2018 black&write! Indigenous Writing and Editing Project in order to get some feedback \u2014 which she did, and won.", "\"Winning was pretty good feedback,\" Simpson jokes.", "Song of the Crocodile is a lament to choice and change, and the unyielding land. It tells the story of three generations of Billymil matriarchs living in the 'gateway town' of Darnmoor where they are watched (and sometimes visited) by ancestral spirits and spirits of the recently deceased, looking out for their descendants and attempting to help them on the right path.", "Ballardong Noongar writer and reviewer Timmah Ball described it as an \"antidote to Anglo-Australian literature\".", "Since being published (by Hachette Australia) Simpson's novel has received critical praise and industry accolades, being longlisted for the Miles Franklin and the Stella Prize and shortlisted for the Victorian Premier's and NSW Premier's Literary Awards \u2014 among others.", "It's just the latest in a growing collection of literary works that have emerged from the black&write! program over the last ten years.", "
Indigenous writing needs Indigenous editors
", "black&write! is an Indigenous-led national project with the dual goals of training First Nations editors to work in the Australian publishing industry, and supporting First Nations authors in their career development.", "Established in 2011 by the State Library of Queensland, the program boasts amongst its writing alumni Ali Cobby Eckermann (Ruby Moonlight), Jane Harrison (Becoming Kirrali Lewis), Claire G. Coleman (Terra Nullius), and Alison Whittaker (Lemons in the Chicken Wire).", "", "
In 2017, Ali Cobby Eckermann won the world's richest literary prize, the Windham Campbell, worth $215,000.\u00a0(Supplied: Nharla Photography)
", "Bundjalung woman Grace Lucas-Pennington, who has been working as an editor for black&write! for six years, says the number of opportunities for Indigenous writers and editors has grown exponentially even in that short time.", "There are more Indigenous books being written across a broad range of genres, and their writers are being featured at writing festivals and winning major prizes.", "In 2019 Melissa Lucashenko became the third Indigenous writer to win the Miles Franklin Award since its establishment in 1957. The following year, Tara June Winch became the fourth.", "black&write! has undeniably played a role in this huge shift in representation and storytelling.", "Each of the two writing fellows receives $10,000 prize money, manuscript development with black&write!, and a publication opportunity with Hachette Australia.", "Lucas-Pennington says black&write! was founded on a simple principle: \"Indigenous stories should be written by Indigenous writers and those writers should be edited by an Indigenous person.", "", "
The free exhibition Sovereign Stories: 10 years of black&write!, curated by Grace Lucas-Pennington (pictured) is running until May 2022 at\u00a0the State Library of Queensland.(Supplied: KiLN)
", "This also meant writers were often forced into the role of cultural educator about everything from the content to the tone or mode of the story.", "\"I've heard of writers having to explain basic things about Australian history, such as the existence and impact of the Stolen Generations, or what it means to live 'under the Act',\" Lucas Pennington says.", "\"Another example would be the tendency to 'correct' Australian Aboriginal English \u2013 which is a separate dialect \u2013 into Standard Australian English, when the author is trying to represent people in their community, who actually do speak AAE. An Indigenous editor brings an ethic and a viewpoint that is inherently more collaborative, that upholds the writer's sovereignty as the story owner.\"", "
A supportive, safe space
", "Simpson says having the opportunity to work with two First Nations editors \u2014 including Lucas-Pennington \u2014 was invaluable.", "\"[The program] was definitely a supportive, safe space to enter into an editorial relationship, as someone with zero experience. I would assume that any first-time writer [working] with a publisher would struggle to feel that safe and that confident in what they were doing.\"", "She says the main difference between working with the black&write! editors and Hachette's editors was their focus.", "\"The publishers [Hachette] were outcome-driven, and that was fine for me because the story was in good shape and could take a bit of bashing. And black&write! editors were people- and narrative-driven.\"", "Simpson appreciates both styles, but in working with her new Hachette editors she really began to appreciate that her book was something that would exist beyond herself.", "It was, in part, why she was so grateful to know there was already a landscape of storytelling created by black&write!", "", "
Simpson is currently undertaking a PhD in composition at Australian National University School of Music, researching the song and story traditions of her Yuwaalaraay homelands.(Supplied:\u00a0Joe Ruckli)
", "With no strict time frame being enforced, the black&write! writers and editors work on a manuscript until everyone is satisfied.", "This slower pace allows the editors to follow Indigenous intellectual and cultural protocols (for example, some writers may need time to check information with their family or community Elders, or seek permission to share that information publicly), and understand the stories in a holistic way.", "Simpson says this also meant she was able to focus purely on her writing craft.", "\"The only worry I had was whether a word was doing the 'right thing' or not. They [the black&write! editors] looked after me, and the story, and the process.\"", "The fact that junior editor Caitlin Murphy was going through a similar learning process was an additional comfort.", "\"It was like looking into the river's reflection; as I was all new to the process, she [Caitlin] was also upskilling to do exactly the same thing \u2014 but as an editor,\" Simpson says.", "
The next generation of editors
", "Reflecting on her initiation into editing, Lucas-Pennington simply remembers being terrified.", "As one of the 2015 black&write! Editing interns, she was assigned Lemons in the Chicken Wire by Gomeroi poet Alison Whittaker, who won the writing fellowship the same year.", "The collection of poems explores life in a rural town, Aboriginality and sexuality.", "\"So you know here was this incredibly smart and talented writer and I was expected to help make the work better, and I had no idea how to go about it because I was a little trainee editor,\" Lucas-Pennington says.", "", "
The current black&write! team is\u00a0(pictured left to right)\u00a0Bianca Valentino,\u00a0Jasmin McGaughey,\u00a0Grace Lucas-Pennington,\u00a0Nadia Johansen and\u00a0Allanah Hunt.\u00a0(Supplied:\u00a0Joe Ruckli)
", "With the support of her mentors, including one of black&write!'s inaugural editors Ellen van Neerven, Lucas-Pennington's confidence in her editing skills grew.", "As well as how to provide constructive feedback and develop author relationships, the main lessons Lucas-Pennington took from her editor fellowship was to trust her editorial instincts.", "\"Just having the confidence to look at a piece of work and say, 'No, this is what I do feel and this is what I think could make it better'\".", "It's telling that several black&write! alumni, including Simpson and Whittaker, have continued to work with Lucas-Pennington beyond the black&write! program.", "\"It's interesting to me that Grace was nervous \u2014 because I was also terrified and trying to find my voice as a poet,\" Whittaker says about those early days.", "But she sees huge value in working with someone who isn't afraid to push back.", "", "
Whittaker published her second collection Blakwork in 2018. Last year, she was the editor of the anthology Fire Front: First Nations Poetry and Power.(Supplied: Whittaker)
", "\"I feel incredibly lucky to have worked with black&write! because I was able to assert a voice that wouldn't have been possible anywhere else.\"", "Prior to the establishment of black&write! you could count the number of First Nations editors on one hand. It's one of the reasons the editing internships were a focus of the program from the very beginning.", "\"I don't think anyone really dreams of being an editor. It's very behind the publishing curtain,\" Lucas-Pennington says.", "In fact, she largely attributes winning the 2015 black&write!'s editing internship to luck and timing. Before applying \u2014 at her mother's suggestion \u2014 Lucas-Pennington had never even dreamed of working in publishing.", "\"But now there's nothing else I'd rather do.\""]
